text: The wicked shall see it, and be grieved; he shall gnash with his teeth, and melt away: the desire of the wicked shall perish.
text_kjv: The wicked shall see it, and be grieved; he shall gnash with his teeth, and melt away: the desire of the wicked shall perish.
text_niv: The wicked man will see and be vexed,he will gnash his teeth and waste away;the longings of the wicked will come to nothing.
text_esv: The wicked man sees it and is angry; he gnashes his teeth and melts away; the desire of the wicked will perish!
text_nlt: The wicked will see this and be infuriated.They will grind their teeth in anger;they will slink away, their hopes thwarted.
text_msg: Someone wicked takes one look and rages,Blusters away but ends up speechless.There's nothing to the dreams of the wicked. Nothing.
text_nasb: The wicked will see it and be vexed, He will gnash his teeth and melt away; The desire of the wicked will perish.
context: Psalm 112 is an acrostic psalm, meaning that each verse (or in some cases, each half-verse) begins with a successive letter of the Hebrew alphabet. This literary structure likely aided memorization and emphasized the completeness or totality of the message. The psalm celebrates the blessings and rewards that come to those who fear the Lord and delight in His commandments. It stands in stark contrast to the fate of the wicked, a common theme in wisdom literature like the Psalms and Proverbs. In ancient Israelite society, wealth and prosperity were often viewed as signs of God's favor, although this wasn't a rigid dogma (as seen in the Book of Job). The righteous were expected to be generous and compassionate, while the wicked were often associated with oppression and injustice. The phrase 'gnash with his teeth' was a common expression of extreme frustration, anger, and despair, often seen in contexts of defeat or loss. 'Melting away' paints a picture of gradual destruction and fading into oblivion, a sharp contrast to the enduring legacy of the righteous described earlier in the psalm. Understanding the historical context of the Hebrew alphabet acrostic adds to the appreciation of the structure and intended memorization. It helps understand why certain phrases and imagery are used to communicate the enduring value of righteousness and its impact on both the righteous and the wicked.
meaning: Theologically, Psalm 112:10 highlights the ultimate futility and self-destruction of wickedness. The 'wicked' are those who reject God's law, pursue selfish ambitions, and often oppress others. Their 'desire' refers not just to fleeting whims, but to their deepest ambitions and plans for worldly success and power. The verse asserts that these desires will ultimately 'perish,' meaning they will come to nothing and leave no lasting good. This perishing is not merely a material loss; it signifies a deeper spiritual bankruptcy. The wicked 'see' the prosperity and righteousness of the blessed individual described throughout the psalm, a prosperity that is not merely financial but also relational and spiritual. This sight intensifies their grief and resentment. 'Gnashing with teeth' is a physical manifestation of their inner torment, a rage against the perceived injustice of the righteous succeeding while they fail. 'Melting away' suggests a gradual erosion of their strength, influence, and even their very being. It's a picture of judgment and the ultimate failure of a life lived in opposition to God. The verse underscores the importance of aligning one's desires with God's will and the inevitable consequences of choosing a path of wickedness. The contrast presented throughout Psalm 112 reveals two opposing ways of living and their distinct outcomes, emphasizing the enduring value of righteousness and the fleeting nature of wickedness.
application: In modern application, Psalm 112:10 serves as a powerful reminder that true success is not measured by worldly gain but by faithfulness to God. We live in a culture that often glorifies wealth, power, and fame, tempting us to pursue these things at any cost. This verse challenges us to re-evaluate our desires and priorities. Are we pursuing goals that align with God's will, or are we chasing after fleeting pleasures and ambitions that will ultimately lead to disappointment and regret? The 'wicked' in this verse can be seen as those who prioritize self-interest above all else, often at the expense of others. Their 'desire' to accumulate wealth or achieve power through unethical means will ultimately 'perish,' leaving them empty and unfulfilled. We, as believers, should strive to live lives of integrity, compassion, and generosity, recognizing that these qualities are far more valuable than any material possession. When we see the apparent success of those who are wicked, we should not be envious or discouraged. Instead, we should remember the ultimate fate of the wicked described in this verse â€“ a fate of grief, frustration, and ultimate destruction. This perspective should encourage us to remain steadfast in our faith, even when it seems difficult or unpopular. Moreover, it calls for empathy. While the verse speaks of the wicked's downfall, it also presents an opportunity to pray for their repentance and transformation. We must remember that God desires all people to come to repentance. Living a life that honors God will inevitably attract both admiration and opposition. The wicked will 'see' our joy, peace, and purpose, and this may cause them to grieve or resent. However, our unwavering commitment to righteousness should serve as a witness to the transformative power of God's grace. Finally, it compels us to examine our own hearts, ensuring that our desires are aligned with God's will. Are we pursuing selfish ambitions, or are we seeking to serve God and others? The answer to this question will determine our ultimate destiny.
prayer: Heavenly Father, help us to see the fleeting nature of worldly success and the enduring value of righteousness. Forgive us for the times when we have chased after selfish ambitions and neglected your will. Grant us the strength to resist the temptation to compromise our integrity for the sake of personal gain. Fill us with compassion for those who are caught in the grip of wickedness, and give us the courage to share your love with them. May our lives be a testament to your grace and truth, so that even those who oppose us may be drawn to you. Help us align our desires with yours, so that we may find true and lasting joy in serving you and others. In Jesus' name, we pray. Amen.

faqs.answer: Psalm 112:10 reminds us that the wicked's prosperity is temporary and ultimately leads to destruction. Focusing on their ultimate fate, rather than their current success, can help diminish envy and strengthen your resolve to remain righteous.
faqs.question: Q1: How can Psalm 112:10 help me deal with feelings of envy when I see the wicked prosper?

faqs.answer: It means that the goals, ambitions, and selfish plans of the wicked will ultimately fail and amount to nothing. Their efforts will not yield lasting value or contribute to God's kingdom; instead, it will vanish.
faqs.question: Q2: What does it mean that 'the desire of the wicked shall perish'?

faqs.answer: No, Psalm 112:10 is not a call to hate the wicked, but a statement about the consequences of their actions. It should motivate us to pray for their repentance and transformation rather than foster hatred.
faqs.question: Q3: Is Psalm 112:10 a call to hate the wicked?

faqs.answer: This verse echoes the theme of divine judgment found throughout Scripture, where those who reject God's ways ultimately face consequences for their actions, aligning with principles found in both the Old and New Testaments.
faqs.question: Q4: How does this verse connect to other teachings in the Bible about judgment?

faqs.answer: 'Gnashing of teeth' signifies extreme frustration, anger, and despair. It portrays the intense emotional torment experienced by the wicked as they witness the success of the righteous and face the failure of their own plans.
